value: regionmaptext=Western Finland is divided into six regions.
region1description=Central Ostrobothnia is both geographically and population-wise one relatively small. Most things of interest can be found in the region's largest city Kokkola.

region2description=The region of Ostrobothnia has a large Swedish-speaking population and a quite interesting archipelago — the Kvarken archipelago — which is slowly rising up from the sea due to post glacial rebound.
region3description=This remarkably flat region is home to several music related events and the country's most famous hard alcohol brand, Koskenkorva.
region4description=This region hosts two UNESCO world heritage sites; Rauma's old town and the Sammallahti bronze age burial site. The sand beaches of Yyteri are also quite popular in the summer.

region5description=Pirkanmaa is usually seen as the heartland of Finnish heavy industry, and the city of Tampere has been called the "Finnish Manchester". However there are plenty to see and do in the city for the traveler — from museums and theatres to the amusement park Särkänniemi.

region6description=The southwesternmost part of Finland is called Finland Proper for historical reasons. The largest city here, Turku, is the oldest city of Finland and hosts a castle and a cathedral that are amongst the oldest in the country. The archipelago that reaches all the way to the Åland islands is another popular destination in the region and especially beautiful in the summer.
/Åbo: the former capital city of Finland
/Tammerfors: the biggest inland town in Scandinavia
/Nådendal: Moominvalley, the home of the Moomins
(Raumo), beautifully preserved old town which is on the UNESCO world heritage list
, home to famously beautiful lakes and ridges
, the former home of a certain rubber boot company that went high-tech
(Närpiö), tomato capital of Finland with their own special Swedish dialect

The region Ostrobothnia, as well as the southern archipelago (bordering to
), has a Swedish speaking majority. Also Turku is bilingual, with the only Swedish university in Finland.
After Helsinki, cities in Western Finland have the best international connections.

value: Saab 2000 of Blue1 at Tampere airport

In addition to a smattering of regional flights,
is the Finnish hub for low-cost airline Ryanair, while
also flights some cheap flights on several other budget airlines. In addition there are direct flights to Vaasa from
Trains between the three major cities of
are very frequent. Seinäjoki and Vaasa are also accessible by train. If you are interested in the towns along the coast, train isn't the best alternative.
Major cities are connected to each other and to Helsinki by frequent buses and most smaller towns have a couple of daily buses to the nearest major city.
There are four daily ferries from
, Silja Line and Viking Line have one day and one overnight departure each. From
(Kapellskär or Grisslehamn) there are connections to
. Further north Vaasanlaivat's Wasa Express brings passengers from

to Vaasa.

The passages over the Sea of Åland and Kvarken (in Gulf of Bothnia) are short enough also for
on a fine day. From Åland one can continue through the
As elsewhere in Finland, driving is the most convenient way to get to remote places. Pay attention to the speed limits on highways — speed cameras are frequent!

Buses are usually the best form of intercity public transportation. The Finnish main north-south train route from Helsinki passes through Tampere, Seinäjoki, Bennäs near Jakobstad and Kokkola so if you are moving about in these areas, or along the Turku–Tampere railway, consider taking the train.
